thread.title: Athletic Bilbao 2-1 Barcelona: Lionel Messi scores but nine man hosts hold on - 5 things we learned
thread.title_full: Athletic Bilbao 2-1 Barcelona: Lionel Messi scores but nine man hosts hold on - 5 things we learned

author: mirror
title: Athletic Bilbao 2-1 Barcelona: Lionel Messi scores but nine man hosts hold on - 5 things we learned
text:
Get FC Barcelona updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Nine-man Athletic Bilbao held out to earn a 2-1 victory against Barcelona in the first leg of their Copa del Rey last 16 clash. 
Goals from Aritz Aduriz and Inaki Williams sent the Basques ahead, although Lionel Messi pulled one back from a spectacular free-kick. 
Neymar was denied a penalty as the Catalans tried to fight their way back into the game, but Raul Garcia and Ander Iturraspe were both dismissed for fouls on the Brazilian star. 
Barcelona pushed for an equaliser but the hosts held out to set up an intriguing second leg next week. 
Here are five things we learned from the game… Neymar is brought down by Xabier Etxeita but the referee says no penalty (Photo: Reuters) Barcelona players protest the decision to the referee (Photo: Reuters) 1. Barca are no longer the best team in Spain 
Although Real Madrid fans have been saying this for weeks, for the first time since Atletico Madrid won the title in 2013-14, it is now hard to argue with the idea that Barcelona are no longer Spanish football’s best team. 
They won the treble in 2014-15 and the double last season, but under Zinedine Zidane Real Madrid have been building up form, and are currently 38 games unbeaten. That in itself does not mean they are the best team in Spain, just the hardest to topple, but the sensational way they dispatched Jorge Sampaoli’s Sevilla on Wednesday night shows they are playing well too. 
While it seemed like they were lucky to go so long unbeaten, they are now playing with a swagger that has left Barcelona’s game this season. Teams like Bilbao now look at the Catalans and see vulnerabilities, chinks in the armour, where they once just saw a fearsome killing machine that chopped down everyone in their wake. Neymar in action with Raul Garcia (Photo: Getty Images) 2. Aritz Aduriz is still going strong 
The Athletic Bilbao forward turns 36 in February but is still proving he is at the peak of his powers week in, week out. 
He opened the scoring like the classic poacher he is, stealing in to head home from close range after Iniesta gave the ball away in midfield. 
Then he set up Inaki Williams with a neat touch to tee up the young forward to blast the second past the helpless Ter Stegen. 
It wouldn’t have been a classic Aduriz display without a moment of nastiness though—the forward is considered one of the dirtier players in the game. 
He jabbed out at Barcelona centre-back Samuel Umtiti’s windpipe, causing consternation as the defender was treated, and more or less got away with it too, with both players receiving yellow cards. Aduriz heads home Bilbao's first goal (Photo: Reuters) Bilbao players celebrate Aduriz's goal (Photo: Getty Images) 3. Luis Enrique holiday claims were wrong 
Barcelona coach Luis Enrique allowed his star players plenty of time off over the festive period, with Messi, Suarez, Neymar and Gerard Pique all given extra holiday to make trips to South America at Christmas. 
When asked about the condition of his star players as they returned from their breaks, the coach insisted they were all fitter than when they left. 
"We have been able to enjoy some well-earned holidays and I am pleasantly surprised with the players since their return," said the Asturian. 
"They have come back in better shape than when they left. I am very happy with the response in training sessions and their performance levels. All my players are ready to compete." 
Unfortunately for him it didn’t seem that way, with Barcelona stunned by two Athletic goals in the first half-an-hour, while his team failed to create many chances of note. Gorka Iraizoz fails to stop Messi's free-kick from crossing the line (Photo: Getty Images) It was a disappointing result for Enrique (Photo: David Ramos) 4. Ivan Rakitic seems to be back in favour 
After he was taken off in the Clasico in the 60th minute, Rakitic went through a period where he was frozen out of the team. 
He did not start five games in eight matches, with his spell out of the side ending when he was picked against Hercules in the Copa del Rey second leg clash at Camp Nou—hardly an accolade, with the key players sent off on holiday before the game. 
But Rakitic played well and scored, with his reward being to be selected for this game, in which Luis Enrique started his strongest side. The Croatian impressed again, one of the Barcelona players that pulled his weight in a disappointing display against tough opponents. 
His defensive durability gives Barcelona something which none of the alternatives for his role—Andre Gomes, Arda Turan, Denis Suarez, Rafinha—can offer. Gerard Pique challenges for the ball (Photo: Reuters) Pique attempts to stop Bilbao's Aduriz (Photo: Reuters) 5. This tie is alive and kicking, literally 
Athletic Bilbao and Barcelona have a history. Even dating back to Maradona’s time with the Catalan giants, when the Argentine was kicked off the field by the Basques. 
Neymar draws the same attention from the Bilbao defence with both Raul Garcia and Iturraspe both sent off for fouls on the Brazilian. 
He will come under the radar next week when the teams meet in the second leg, along with Aduriz after his altercation with Umtiti. 
But as well as the various individual battles which started here and will continue, this is one of the few last 16 ties which is still unresolved. Real Madrid, for example, are virtually through against Sevilla, while the same goes for Atletico against Las Palmas and Celta Vigo against Valencia. 
This one is far from over. poll loading Will Barcelona turn it round in the second leg? 0+ VOTES SO FAR
